trans-unit.source: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword
trans-unit.target: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword

trans-unit.source: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword
trans-unit.target: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword
trans-unit.target: System.Delegate and the `delegate` keyword

trans-unit.source: Previous
trans-unit.target: Previous

trans-unit.source: This article will cover the classes in the .NET framework that support delegates, and how those map to the `delegate` keyword.
trans-unit.target: This article will cover the classes in the .NET framework that support delegates, and how those map to the `delegate` keyword.

trans-unit.source: Defining Delegate Types
trans-unit.target: Defining Delegate Types

trans-unit.source: Let's start with the 'delegate' keyword, because that's primarily what you will use as you work with delegates.
trans-unit.target: Let's start with the 'delegate' keyword, because that's primarily what you will use as you work with delegates.

trans-unit.source: The code that the compiler generates when you use the `delegate` keyword will map to method calls that invoke members of the @System.Delegate and @System.MulticastDelegate classes.
trans-unit.target: The code that the compiler generates when you use the `delegate` keyword will map to method calls that invoke members of the @System.Delegate and @System.MulticastDelegate classes.

trans-unit.source: You define a delegate type using syntax that is similar to defining a method signature.
trans-unit.target: You define a delegate type using syntax that is similar to defining a method signature.

trans-unit.source: You just add the `delegate` keyword to the definition.
trans-unit.target: You just add the `delegate` keyword to the definition.

trans-unit.source: Let's continue to use the List.Sort() method as our example.
trans-unit.target: Let's continue to use the List.Sort() method as our example.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to create a type for the comparison delegate:
trans-unit.target: The first step is to create a type for the comparison delegate:

trans-unit.source: The compiler generates a class, derived from `System.Delegate` that matches the signature used (in this case, a method that returns an integer, and has two arguments).
trans-unit.target: The compiler generates a class, derived from `System.Delegate` that matches the signature used (in this case, a method that returns an integer, and has two arguments).

trans-unit.source: The type of that delegate is `Comparison`.
trans-unit.target: The type of that delegate is `Comparison`.

trans-unit.source: The `Comparison` delegate type is a generic type.
trans-unit.target: The `Comparison` delegate type is a generic type.

trans-unit.source: For details on generics see [here](generics.md).
trans-unit.target: For details on generics see [here](generics.md).

trans-unit.source: Notice that the syntax may appear as though it is declaring a variable, but it is actually declaring a *type*.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the syntax may appear as though it is declaring a variable, but it is actually declaring a *type*.

trans-unit.source: You can define delegate types inside classes, directly inside namespaces, or even in the global namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can define delegate types inside classes, directly inside namespaces, or even in the global namespace.

trans-unit.source: Declaring delegate types (or other types) directly in the global namespace is not recommended.
trans-unit.target: Declaring delegate types (or other types) directly in the global namespace is not recommended.

trans-unit.source: The compiler also generates add and remove handlers for this new type so that clients of this class can add and remove methods from an instance's invocation list.
trans-unit.target: The compiler also generates add and remove handlers for this new type so that clients of this class can add and remove methods from an instance's invocation list.

trans-unit.source: The compiler will enforce that the signature of the method being added or removed matches the signature used when declaring the method.
trans-unit.target: The compiler will enforce that the signature of the method being added or removed matches the signature used when declaring the method.

trans-unit.source: Declaring instances of delegates
trans-unit.target: Declaring instances of delegates

trans-unit.source: After defining the delegate, you can create an instance of that type.
trans-unit.target: After defining the delegate, you can create an instance of that type.

trans-unit.source: Like all variables in C#, you cannot declare delegate instances directly in a namespace, or in the global namespace.
trans-unit.target: Like all variables in C#, you cannot declare delegate instances directly in a namespace, or in the global namespace.

trans-unit.source: The type of the variable is `Comparison<T>`, the delegate type defined earlier.
trans-unit.target: The type of the variable is `Comparison<T>`, the delegate type defined earlier.

trans-unit.source: The name of the variable is `comparator`.
trans-unit.target: The name of the variable is `comparator`.

trans-unit.source: That code snippet above declared a member variable inside a class.
trans-unit.target: That code snippet above declared a member variable inside a class.

trans-unit.source: You can also declare delegate variables that are local variables, or arguments to methods.
trans-unit.target: You can also declare delegate variables that are local variables, or arguments to methods.

trans-unit.source: Invoking Delegates
trans-unit.target: Invoking Delegates

trans-unit.source: You invoke the methods that are in the invocation list of a delegate by calling that delegate.
trans-unit.target: You invoke the methods that are in the invocation list of a delegate by calling that delegate.

trans-unit.source: Inside the `Sort()` method, the code will call the comparison method to determine which order to place objects:
trans-unit.target: Inside the `Sort()` method, the code will call the comparison method to determine which order to place objects:

trans-unit.source: In the line above, the code *invokes* the method attached to the delegate.
trans-unit.target: In the line above, the code *invokes* the method attached to the delegate.

trans-unit.source: You treat the variable as a method name, and invoke it using normal method call syntax.
trans-unit.target: You treat the variable as a method name, and invoke it using normal method call syntax.

trans-unit.source: That line of code makes an unsafe assumption: There's no guarantee that a target has been added to the delegate.
trans-unit.target: That line of code makes an unsafe assumption: There's no guarantee that a target has been added to the delegate.

trans-unit.source: If no targets have been attached, the line above would cause a `NullReferenceException` to be thrown.
trans-unit.target: If no targets have been attached, the line above would cause a `NullReferenceException` to be thrown.

trans-unit.source: The idioms used to address this problem are more complicated than a simple null-check, and are covered later in this [series](delegates-patterns.md).
trans-unit.target: The idioms used to address this problem are more complicated than a simple null-check, and are covered later in this [series](delegates-patterns.md).

trans-unit.source: Assigning, Adding and removing Invocation Targets
trans-unit.target: Assigning, Adding and removing Invocation Targets

trans-unit.source: That's how a delegate type is defined, and how delegate instances are declared and invoked.
trans-unit.target: That's how a delegate type is defined, and how delegate instances are declared and invoked.

trans-unit.source: Developers that want to use the `List.Sort()` method need to define a method whose signature matches the delegate type definition, and assign it to the delegate used by the sort method.
trans-unit.target: Developers that want to use the `List.Sort()` method need to define a method whose signature matches the delegate type definition, and assign it to the delegate used by the sort method.

trans-unit.source: This assignment adds the method to the invocation list of that delegate object.
trans-unit.target: This assignment adds the method to the invocation list of that delegate object.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you wanted to sort a list of strings by their length.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you wanted to sort a list of strings by their length.

trans-unit.source: Your comparison function might be the following:
trans-unit.target: Your comparison function might be the following:

trans-unit.source: The method is declared as a private method.
trans-unit.target: The method is declared as a private method.

trans-unit.source: That's fine.
trans-unit.target: That's fine.

trans-unit.source: You may not want this method to be part of your public interface.
trans-unit.target: You may not want this method to be part of your public interface.

trans-unit.source: It can still be used as the comparison method when attached to a delegate.
trans-unit.target: It can still be used as the comparison method when attached to a delegate.

trans-unit.source: The calling code will have this method attached to the target list of the delegate object, and can access it through that delegate.
trans-unit.target: The calling code will have this method attached to the target list of the delegate object, and can access it through that delegate.

trans-unit.source: You create that relationship by passing that method to the `List.Sort()` method:
trans-unit.target: You create that relationship by passing that method to the `List.Sort()` method:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the method name is used, without parentheses.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the method name is used, without parentheses.

trans-unit.source: Using the method as an argument tells the compiler to convert the method reference into a reference that can be used as a delegate invocation target, and attach that method as an invocation target.
trans-unit.target: Using the method as an argument tells the compiler to convert the method reference into a reference that can be used as a delegate invocation target, and attach that method as an invocation target.

trans-unit.source: You could also have been explicit by declaring a variable of type 'Comparison<string>` and doing an assignment:
trans-unit.target: You could also have been explicit by declaring a variable of type 'Comparison<string>` and doing an assignment:

trans-unit.source: In uses where the method being used as a delegate target is a small method, it's common to use [Lambda Expression](lambda-expressions.md) syntax to perform the assignment:
trans-unit.target: In uses where the method being used as a delegate target is a small method, it's common to use [Lambda Expression](lambda-expressions.md) syntax to perform the assignment:

trans-unit.source: Using Lambda Expressions for delegate targets is covered more in a [later section](delegates-patterns.md).
trans-unit.target: Using Lambda Expressions for delegate targets is covered more in a [later section](delegates-patterns.md).

trans-unit.source: The Sort() example typically attaches a single target method to the delegate.
trans-unit.target: The Sort() example typically attaches a single target method to the delegate.

trans-unit.source: However, delegate objects do support invocation lists that have multiple target methods attached to a delegate object.
trans-unit.target: However, delegate objects do support invocation lists that have multiple target methods attached to a delegate object.

trans-unit.source: Delegate and MulticastDelegate classes
trans-unit.target: Delegate and MulticastDelegate classes

trans-unit.source: The language support desccribed above provides the features and support you'll typically need to work with delegates.
trans-unit.target: The language support desccribed above provides the features and support you'll typically need to work with delegates.

trans-unit.source: These features are built on two classes in the .NET Core framework: @System.Delegate and @"System.MulticastDelegate".
trans-unit.target: These features are built on two classes in the .NET Core framework: @System.Delegate and @"System.MulticastDelegate".

trans-unit.source: The `System.Delegate` class, and its single direct sub-class, `System.MulticastDelegate`, provide the framework support for creating delegates, registering methods as delegate targets, and invoking all methods that are registered as a delegate target.
trans-unit.target: The `System.Delegate` class, and its single direct sub-class, `System.MulticastDelegate`, provide the framework support for creating delegates, registering methods as delegate targets, and invoking all methods that are registered as a delegate target.

trans-unit.source: Interestingly, the `System.Delegate` and `System.MulticastDelegate` classes are not themselves delegate types.
trans-unit.target: Interestingly, the `System.Delegate` and `System.MulticastDelegate` classes are not themselves delegate types.

trans-unit.source: They do provide the basis for all specific delegate types.
trans-unit.target: They do provide the basis for all specific delegate types.

trans-unit.source: That same language design process mandated that you cannot declare a class that derives from `Delegate` or `MulticastDelegate`.
trans-unit.target: That same language design process mandated that you cannot declare a class that derives from `Delegate` or `MulticastDelegate`.

trans-unit.source: The C# language rules prohibit it.
trans-unit.target: The C# language rules prohibit it.

trans-unit.source: Instead, the C# compiler creates instances of a class derived from `MulticastDelegate` when you use the C# language keyword to declare delegate types.
trans-unit.target: Instead, the C# compiler creates instances of a class derived from `MulticastDelegate` when you use the C# language keyword to declare delegate types.

trans-unit.source: This design has its roots in the first release of C# and .NET.
trans-unit.target: This design has its roots in the first release of C# and .NET.

trans-unit.source: One goal for the design team was to ensure that the language enforced type safety when using delegates.
trans-unit.target: One goal for the design team was to ensure that the language enforced type safety when using delegates.

trans-unit.source: That meant ensuring that delegates were invoked with the right type and number of arguments.
trans-unit.target: That meant ensuring that delegates were invoked with the right type and number of arguments.

trans-unit.source: And, that any return type was correctly indicated at compile time.
trans-unit.target: And, that any return type was correctly indicated at compile time.

trans-unit.source: Delegates were part of the 1.0 .NET release, which was before generics.
trans-unit.target: Delegates were part of the 1.0 .NET release, which was before generics.

trans-unit.source: The best way to enforce this type safety was for the compiler to create the concrete delegate classes that represented the method signature being used.
trans-unit.target: The best way to enforce this type safety was for the compiler to create the concrete delegate classes that represented the method signature being used.

trans-unit.source: Even though you cannot create derived classes directly, you will use the methods defined on these classes.
trans-unit.target: Even though you cannot create derived classes directly, you will use the methods defined on these classes.

trans-unit.source: Let's go through the most common methods that you will use when you work with delegates.
trans-unit.target: Let's go through the most common methods that you will use when you work with delegates.

trans-unit.source: The first, most important fact to remember is that every delegate you work with is derived from `MulticastDelegate`.
trans-unit.target: The first, most important fact to remember is that every delegate you work with is derived from `MulticastDelegate`.

trans-unit.source: A multicast delegate means that more than one method target can be invoked when invoking through a delegate.
trans-unit.target: A multicast delegate means that more than one method target can be invoked when invoking through a delegate.

trans-unit.source: The original design considered making a distinction between delegates where only one target method could be attached and invoked, and delegates where multiple target methods could be attached and invoked.
trans-unit.target: The original design considered making a distinction between delegates where only one target method could be attached and invoked, and delegates where multiple target methods could be attached and invoked.

trans-unit.source: That distinction proved to be less useful in practice than originally thought.
trans-unit.target: That distinction proved to be less useful in practice than originally thought.

trans-unit.source: The two different classes were already created, and have been in the framework since its initial public release.
trans-unit.target: The two different classes were already created, and have been in the framework since its initial public release.

trans-unit.source: The methods that you will use the most with delegates are `Invoke()` and `BeginInvoke()` / `EndInvoke()`.
trans-unit.target: The methods that you will use the most with delegates are `Invoke()` and `BeginInvoke()` / `EndInvoke()`.

trans-unit.source: will invoke all the methods that have been attached to a particular delegate instance.
trans-unit.target: will invoke all the methods that have been attached to a particular delegate instance.

trans-unit.source: As you saw above, you typically invoke delegates using the method call syntax on the delegate variable.
trans-unit.target: As you saw above, you typically invoke delegates using the method call syntax on the delegate variable.

trans-unit.source: As you'll see [later in this series](delegates-patterns.md), there are patterns that work directly with these methods.
trans-unit.target: As you'll see [later in this series](delegates-patterns.md), there are patterns that work directly with these methods.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've seen the language syntax and the classes that support delegates, let's examine how strongly typed delegates are used, created and invoked.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've seen the language syntax and the classes that support delegates, let's examine how strongly typed delegates are used, created and invoked.
